g.title: Rectangle
g.text: Bridge (=Handle/body)Separate abstraction and implementation so both can change independently

g.title: Rectangle.45
g.desc: The same implementation should be shared amongst different ab...
g.text: The same implementation should be shared amongst different abstractions

g.title: Rectangle.47
g.desc: An object should be capable to switch implementation during r...
g.text: An object should be capable to switch implementation during runtime

g.title: Rectangle.52
g.desc: We want to introduce software layering
g.text: We want to introduce software layering

g.title: Folded Corner.54
g.desc: Separating high level logic from low level logic introduces l...

g.text: Separating high level logic from low level logic introduces layering. Layering ensures ease of change, but also an increase in readability and testability, because everything is ‘well’ divided.

g.title: Folded Corner.57
g.desc: Bridge pattern introduces an extra form of indirection, by se...

g.text: Bridge pattern introduces an extra form of indirection, by separating the implementation from the abstract. This could make the code harder to comprehend in contrast to having the implementation and abstraction in the same place. Especially when implementation and abstraction have a high level of cohesion.

g.title: Folded Corner.69
g.desc: The Bridge pattern ensures layering. Via layering we separate...

g.text: The Bridge pattern ensures layering. Via layering we separate low levels details from the higher, more abstract logic. This ensures readability, reusability and testability. Readability, because we can first read our code more from an abstract point of view, detect the point of interest and navigate into the details. Reusability, because multiple abstractions could re-use the same implementation. Testability, because we can test our code more isolated (our ‘problem’ window is smaller).

g.title: Folded Corner.75
g.desc: The sharing of implementation reflects on the inheritance VS ...

g.text: The sharing of implementation reflects on the inheritance VS composition discussion. Our inheritance tree can grown exponentially incase two dimensions are ‘intertwined’. Sharing implementation via inheritance is thus not ideal. The separation of these dimensions makes it possible to share the same implementation between multiple abstractions using composition.

g.title: Rectangle.82
g.desc: Binary compatibility of a library is required
g.text: Binary compatibility of a library is required

g.title: Folded Corner.86
g.desc: We can assure binary compatibility incase implementation can ...

g.text: We can assure binary compatibility incase implementation can ‘evolve’ separately from its abstraction. The pImpl (pointer to implementation) idiom in C++ is a language specific implementation of the Bridge pattern that ensures binary compatibility. E.g. in C++ libraries could be ‘packaged’ in the form of a DLL (Dynamic Linked Library). A change in the header, serving as an interface towards the client, of such a DLL could result in binary incompatibility. E.g. when we change or add a private member, the size of the object changes and thus re-compilation is required. The Bridge pattern overcomes this.

g.title: Rectangle.91
g.desc: The inheritance tree grows exponential for relative simple ch...
g.text: The inheritance tree grows exponential for relative simple changes

g.title: Folded Corner.93
g.desc: A small addition in functionality of a class requires us to i...

g.text: A small addition in functionality of a class requires us to introduce a lot of new sub-classes. This is often an indication that we need to introduce serval parallel class hierarchies in order to overcome exponential growth and instead have linear class growth. Advantages that arise from separating these hierarchies are independent growth of both hierarchies and reusability. Multiple sub classes from the abstract hierarchy can benefit from the same sub classes of the implementation hierarchy. The bridge pattern ‘shifts’ a increase in class construction to an increase in object construction.

g.title: Folded Corner.97
g.desc: This is closely related to ‘binary compatibility’. The separa...

g.text: This is closely related to ‘binary compatibility’. The separation of the implementation from the abstraction can be beneficial for our clients. Clients will be hidden from the implementation and thus will not have to re-compile in case the implementation changes. The pImpl (pointer to implementation) idiom in C++ is a language specific implementation to reduce the re-compilation time. This can be very beneficial in large software systems.

g.title: Folded Corner.104
g.desc: The Bridge pattern ensures that we can change or extend the i...

g.text: The Bridge pattern ensures that we can change or extend the implementation of our abstraction, without modifying the abstraction. E.g. incase of layering, the low level details can change without affecting the higher level logic. This compliments the Dependency Inversion Principle, which helps realizing the Open Closed Principle. The separation between implementation and abstraction is beneficial in testing, because it improves ‘mockability’.
